segment.source: Date and time controls let you view and set the date and time.
segment.target: Date and time controls let you view and set the date and time.

segment.source: This article provides design guidelines and helps you pick the right control.
segment.target: This article provides design guidelines and helps you pick the right control.

segment.source: Guidelines for date and time controls
segment.target: Guidelines for date and time controls

segment.source: Calendar, date, and time controls
segment.target: Calendar, date, and time controls

segment.source: Date and time controls give you standard, localized ways to let a user view and set date and time values in your app.
segment.target: Date and time controls give you standard, localized ways to let a user view and set date and time values in your app.

segment.source: This article provides design guidelines and helps you pick the right control.
segment.target: This article provides design guidelines and helps you pick the right control.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: CalendarView class
segment.target: CalendarView class

segment.source: CalendarDatePicker class
segment.target: CalendarDatePicker class

segment.source: DatePicker class
segment.target: DatePicker class

segment.source: TimePicker class
segment.target: TimePicker class

segment.source: Which date or time control should you use?
segment.target: Which date or time control should you use?

segment.source: There are four date and time controls to choose from; the control you use depends on your scenario.
segment.target: There are four date and time controls to choose from; the control you use depends on your scenario.

segment.source: Use this info to pick the right control to use in your app.
segment.target: Use this info to pick the right control to use in your app.

segment.source: Calendar view
segment.target: Calendar view

segment.source: Example of calendar view
segment.target: Example of calendar view

segment.source: Use to pick a single date or a range of dates from an always visible calendar.
segment.target: Use to pick a single date or a range of dates from an always visible calendar.

segment.source: Calendar date picker
segment.target: Calendar date picker

segment.source: Example of calendar date picker
segment.target: Example of calendar date picker

segment.source: Use to pick a single date from a contextual calendar.
segment.target: Use to pick a single date from a contextual calendar.

segment.source: Date picker
segment.target: Date picker

segment.source: Example of date picker
segment.target: Example of date picker

segment.source: Use to pick a single known date when contextual info isn't important.
segment.target: Use to pick a single known date when contextual info isn't important.

segment.source: Time picker
segment.target: Time picker

segment.source: Example of time picker
segment.target: Example of time picker

segment.source: Use to pick a single time value.
segment.target: Use to pick a single time value.

segment.source: Calendar view
segment.target: Calendar view

segment.source: CalendarView lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.
segment.target: CalendarView lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.

segment.source: A user can select a single date or a range of dates.
segment.target: A user can select a single date or a range of dates.

segment.source: It doesn't have a picker surface and the calendar is always visible.
segment.target: It doesn't have a picker surface and the calendar is always visible.

segment.source: The calendar view is made up of 3 separate views: the month view, year view, and decade view.
segment.target: The calendar view is made up of 3 separate views: the month view, year view, and decade view.

segment.source: By default, it starts with the month view open, but you can specify any view as the startup view.
segment.target: By default, it starts with the month view open, but you can specify any view as the startup view.

segment.source: Example of calendar date picker
segment.target: Example of calendar date picker

segment.source: If you need to let a user select multiple dates, you must use a CalendarView.
segment.target: If you need to let a user select multiple dates, you must use a CalendarView.

segment.source: If you need to let a user pick only a single date and don’t need a calendar to be always visible, consider using a CalendarDatePicker or DatePicker control.
segment.target: If you need to let a user pick only a single date and don’t need a calendar to be always visible, consider using a CalendarDatePicker or DatePicker control.

segment.source: Calendar date picker
segment.target: Calendar date picker

segment.source: CalendarDatePicker is a drop down control that’s optimized for picking a single date from a calendar view where contextual information like the day of the week or fullness of the calendar is important.
segment.target: CalendarDatePicker is a drop down control that’s optimized for picking a single date from a calendar view where contextual information like the day of the week or fullness of the calendar is important.

segment.source: You can modify the calendar to provide additional context or to limit available dates.
segment.target: You can modify the calendar to provide additional context or to limit available dates.

segment.source: The entry point displays placeholder text if a date has not been set; otherwise, it displays the chosen date.
segment.target: The entry point displays placeholder text if a date has not been set; otherwise, it displays the chosen date.

segment.source: When the user selects the entry point, a calendar view expands for the user to make a date selection.
segment.target: When the user selects the entry point, a calendar view expands for the user to make a date selection.

segment.source: The calendar view overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.
segment.target: The calendar view overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.

segment.source: Example of calendar date picker
segment.target: Example of calendar date picker

segment.source: Use a calendar date picker for things like choosing an appointment or departure date.
segment.target: Use a calendar date picker for things like choosing an appointment or departure date.

segment.source: Date picker
segment.target: Date picker

segment.source: The DatePicker control provides a standardized way to choose a specific date.
segment.target: The DatePicker control provides a standardized way to choose a specific date.

segment.source: The entry point displays the chosen date, and when the user selects the entry point, a picker surface expands vertically from the middle for the user to make a selection.
segment.target: The entry point displays the chosen date, and when the user selects the entry point, a picker surface expands vertically from the middle for the user to make a selection.

segment.source: The date picker overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.
segment.target: The date picker overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.

segment.source: Example of the date picker expanding
segment.target: Example of the date picker expanding

segment.source: Use a date picker to let a user pick a known date, such as a date of birth, where the context of the calendar is not important.
segment.target: Use a date picker to let a user pick a known date, such as a date of birth, where the context of the calendar is not important.

segment.source: Time picker
segment.target: Time picker

segment.source: The TimePicker is used to select a single time value for things like appointments or a departure time.
segment.target: The TimePicker is used to select a single time value for things like appointments or a departure time.

segment.source: It's a static display that is set by the user or in code, but it doesn't update to display the current time.
segment.target: It's a static display that is set by the user or in code, but it doesn't update to display the current time.

segment.source: The entry point displays the chosen time, and when the user selects the entry point, a picker surface expands vertically from the middle for the user to make a selection.
segment.target: The entry point displays the chosen time, and when the user selects the entry point, a picker surface expands vertically from the middle for the user to make a selection.

segment.source: The time picker overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.
segment.target: The time picker overlays other UI; it doesn't push other UI out of the way.

segment.source: Example of the time picker expanding
segment.target: Example of the time picker expanding

segment.source: Use a time picker to let a user pick a single time value.
segment.target: Use a time picker to let a user pick a single time value.

segment.source: Create a date or time control
segment.target: Create a date or time control

segment.source: See these articles for info and examples specific to each date and time control.
segment.target: See these articles for info and examples specific to each date and time control.

segment.target: Date picker

segment.target: Time Picker

segment.source: Globalization
segment.target: Globalization

segment.source: The XAML date controls support each of the calendar systems supported by Windows.
segment.target: The XAML date controls support each of the calendar systems supported by Windows.

segment.source: These calendars are specified in the Windows.Globalization.CalendarIdentifiers class.
segment.target: These calendars are specified in the Windows.Globalization.CalendarIdentifiers class.

segment.source: Each control uses the correct calendar for your app's default language, or you can set the CalendarIdentifier property to use a specific calendar system.
segment.target: Each control uses the correct calendar for your app's default language, or you can set the CalendarIdentifier property to use a specific calendar system.

segment.source: The time picker control supports each of the clock systems specified in the Windows.Globalization.ClockIdentifiers class.
segment.target: The time picker control supports each of the clock systems specified in the Windows.Globalization.ClockIdentifiers class.

segment.source: You can set the ClockIdentifier property to use either a 12-hour clock or 24-hour clock.
segment.target: You can set the ClockIdentifier property to use either a 12-hour clock or 24-hour clock.

segment.source: The type of the property is String, but you must use values that correspond to the static string properties of the ClockIdentifiers class.
segment.target: The type of the property is String, but you must use values that correspond to the static string properties of the ClockIdentifiers class.

segment.source: These are: TwelveHour (the string "12HourClock")and TwentyFourHour (the string "24HourClock").
segment.target: These are: TwelveHour (the string "12HourClock")and TwentyFourHour (the string "24HourClock").

segment.source: "12HourClock" is the default value.
segment.target: "12HourClock" is the default value.

segment.source: DateTime and Calendar values
segment.target: DateTime and Calendar values

segment.source: The date objects used in the XAML date and time controls have a different representation depending on your programming language.
segment.target: The date objects used in the XAML date and time controls have a different representation depending on your programming language.

segment.source: C# and Visual Basic use the System.DateTimeOffset structure that is part of .NET.
segment.target: C# and Visual Basic use the System.DateTimeOffset structure that is part of .NET.

segment.source: C++/CX uses the Windows::Foundation::DateTime structure.
segment.target: C++/CX uses the Windows::Foundation::DateTime structure.

segment.source: A related concept is the Calendar class, which influences how dates are interpreted in context.
segment.target: A related concept is the Calendar class, which influences how dates are interpreted in context.

segment.source: All Windows Runtime apps can use the Windows.Globalization.Calendar class.
segment.target: All Windows Runtime apps can use the Windows.Globalization.Calendar class.

segment.source: C# and Visual Basic apps can alternatively use the System.Globalization.Calendar class, which has very similar functionality.
segment.target: C# and Visual Basic apps can alternatively use the System.Globalization.Calendar class, which has very similar functionality.

segment.source: (Windows Runtime apps can use the base .NET Calendar class but not the specific implementations; for example, GregorianCalendar.)
segment.target: (Windows Runtime apps can use the base .NET Calendar class but not the specific implementations; for example, GregorianCalendar.)

segment.source: .NET also supports a type named DateTime, which is implicitly convertible to a DateTimeOffset.
segment.target: .NET also supports a type named DateTime, which is implicitly convertible to a DateTimeOffset.

segment.source: So you might see a "DateTime" type being used in .NET code that's used to set values that are really DateTimeOffset.
segment.target: So you might see a "DateTime" type being used in .NET code that's used to set values that are really DateTimeOffset.

segment.source: For more info on the difference between DateTime and DateTimeOffset, see Remarks in the DateTimeOffset class.
segment.target: For more info on the difference between DateTime and DateTimeOffset, see Remarks in the DateTimeOffset class.

segment.source: NoteProperties that take date objects can't be set as a XAML attribute string, because the Windows Runtime XAML parser doesn't have a conversion logic for converting strings to dates as DateTime/DateTimeOffset objects.
segment.target: NoteProperties that take date objects can't be set as a XAML attribute string, because the Windows Runtime XAML parser doesn't have a conversion logic for converting strings to dates as DateTime/DateTimeOffset objects.

segment.source: You typically set these values in code.
segment.target: You typically set these values in code.

segment.source: Another possible technique is to define a date that's available as a data object or in the data context, then set the property as a XAML attribute that references a \{Binding\} markup extension expression that can access the date as data.
segment.target: Another possible technique is to define a date that's available as a data object or in the data context, then set the property as a XAML attribute that references a \{Binding\} markup extension expression that can access the date as data.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
